results.title: Beloved
results.creator_credit: Daniel Zinkant, Elle Farnham, First Light and Suited & Booted Studios
results.brief_description: Through the main protagonist Dave, we hear and see what it is like to be in love and have those feelings trapped inside. As we are let into Dave’s world, we see him and a group of friends as they leave school and embark on their journey home. The film flicks between two worlds of fantasy and real-life as the journey progresses. As the narrative comes to an end, we watch the three friends depart and Dave is left alone. His love unknown, unsaid but only understood by the viewer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Daniel Zinkant, Elle Farnham, First Light and Suited & Booted Studios

results.title: Pirates of the Indian Ocean
results.creator_credit: Enamul Khan, Omni Rahman, Rafi Rahman, First Light, Northamptonshire Bangladeshi Association and Wind & Foster Media
results.brief_description: Clumsy but lovable DJ duo Mankind and Small-Steps have built a devoted following to their pirate radio show. Raging against the machine in their own inimitable style, will they reach the top of radio programming or be caught on the wrong side of the law before they reach their dream?

results.title: The Box
results.creator_credit: Felix Drake, Patrick Young, Phoebe Flemming, eShed, First Light and Watershed
results.brief_description: This short drama is a tight observation of family life during the recession. Shot in a single living room, we see the ebb and flow of family life reflected in some pivotal moments through a particularly difficult time. However, the digital hearth remains a constant source of comfort.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Interview with Jan Chapman and Janet Patterson
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery, Mike Kenneally and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The 2009 film ‘Bright Star’ (directed by Jane Campion) tells the story of the romance between the English poet John Keats (1795 - 1821) and Fanny Brawne.
In this interview, ‘Bright Star’ producer Jan Chapman and costume designer Janet Patterson discuss the creative process behind costume design, and the design choices that went into making one of the costumes for the character Fanny Brawne (played in the film by Abbie Cornish).
The character’s crimson gown costume was on display during the ACMI Melbourne Winter Masterpieces ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition (2013).
Clips from ‘Bright Star’ (2009) courtesy of Hopscotch Films.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Aden Porter, Joshua Ash-Miller, Laurence Gunther and Schonn-Pierre Hirst
results.brief_description:
The theme of belonging is explored by looking at rejection based on stereotypes in the schoolyard, and the effect that had on the victim. Also shown in this animated short is the impact an accepting group has on that person.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Secondary”, Year 10, St John’s Grammar School, South Australia, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Wish
results.creator_credit: Araine Moir, Elizabeth Kuiper and Emily Abernethy
results.brief_description:
A young girl is transported into a fantasy world where her birthday wishes manifest into something beyond her control. This film questions the importance we place on superficial and materialistic desires.

Under the category ‘Best Overall Secondary School Entry’, Year 12, Presbyterian Ladies’ College, Peppermint Grove, WA, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Proud 2 Be Me!
results.creator_credit: Amy Rowe, Charlotte Kinsella, Chloe McKenna, Hannah Petrowski, Isabelle Tonna, Jessica Smith and Leah Felsbourg
results.brief_description:
A story of a little, white monster who feels like he doesn’t belong. He tries to make himself fit in, which doesn’t quite work out. The other little monsters finally decide that they like the little white monster just the way he is.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Primary’, Years 5 and 6, St Luke’s Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

group_siblings.creator_credit: Liam Blake

results.title: You don't belong here [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
By staying true to your own ideals you will find a group of unique individuals where everyone belongs. A man is shipwrecked on a distant island. He must search the island for a tribe to live in by avoiding obstacles and collecting gems along the way. These tribes will take you in but on the condition you behave like them. You decline their offer saying you have a right to be yourself. You are then banished and must avoid members of these tribes as you continue your search. They attempt to catch you as you dont belong. Finally you come across a tribe that accepts you for who you are. They are all individuals and make you feel like you belong.

Under the category ‘Primary Videogames’, Liam Blake, Hope Valley, SA, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: Unshaded
results.brief_description:
‘Unshaded’ is a stop-motion animation made from plasticine. It explores the notion that no matter who you are, there is always a place of belonging for you. The animation is initially shot in a black and white world, reflecting the character’s thoughts of loneliness and insecurity. The character is confronted by unfamiliar creatures who seek to gain their colour back by signalling to him to tap them on the head. He does this and in return his world is restored to colour. The character realises that together they can bring happiness to each other and ultimately belong even though they may have evident differences.

Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Hayley Warnock, Benalla, Victoria, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

‘Unshaded’ is a stop-motion animation made from plasticine. It explores the notion that no matter who you are, there is always a place of belonging for you. The animation is initially shot in a black and white world, reflecting the character’s thoughts of loneliness and insecurity. The character is confronted by unfamiliar creatures who seek to gain their colour back by signalling to him to tap them on the head. He does this and in return his world is restored to colour. The character realises that together they can bring happiness to each other and ultimately belong even though they may have evident differences.

Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Hayley Warnock, Benalla, Victoria, was the Screen It 2012 winner.
